Articles.Content:
I'll keep this short and sweet.

The scientific team on Kerbal has decided that the amount of waste products put into the atmosphere by large engines are damaging the environment too heavily.

Thanks to impending global warming, political types have agreed, and have placed a blanket ban on all engines.

Except, the LV-1 and LV-1R.

But space exploration must continue! We cannot be stopped! As such, the Kerbal Space Program has issued a challenge to it's best and brightest to see what can be done.

Build a rocket that can make it into space with at least one Kerbal using only the LV-1R and/or the LV-1 engines. Remember to take pictures and/or video along the way to prove it!

The Kerbal Space Government is NOT interested in cheaters, hacks, or wizards. NO DEBUG MENU.

Points!

Bronze: Make it to space! Send a Kerbal on a space walk to prove it!

Silver: Make it into orbit! Show your periapsis to prove it!

Gold: Land safely on Mun! Show your Kerbal on Mun to prove it!

Platinum: Send them beyond Mun! Land safely on Duna!

If somebody can do better than Duna, then I think you just win instantly. But I'd definitely like a look at that spacecraft!

I'd love to see photos and videos of attempts too, cause that'd just be funny!

I like this challenge's background story. It reflects nicely the rationality of our current intercourse with climate.

However the pointing system is a bit unclear to me. What does "send them beyond Mun" mean? For instance, landing on Minmus is easier than on Mun. Getting interplanetary is even easier. And to prove orbit, the periapsis is the important one, not the apoapsis.

It's not really enviromentally friendly as it might appear. The least polluting engine should be the one which gives the most thrust per its mass, meaning it's the most efficient engine. Banning a really efficient engine and replacing it with tons of less efficient LV-1R engines requires even more engines to cover for the lost efficiency.

Consequently, you emit more waste into the environment.

This is actually why lots of "eco hype" stuff is downright crap that just fills someone's pocket.
